1126273238278053888.text: Let me be clear on this. It doesn't matter how much the hack is for. If hack is for X BTC, the cost to reorg is at least X BTC + Y block rewards where Y is the number of blocks to reorg, given the game theory. It could 10 BTC or 1M BTC, it's not profitable.

1126163296908972032.text: A reorg is indistinguishable from an attack. The bitcoin network immune system works the same way for both without prejudice. That's what makes it a great network. The rules are the same for everybody.

1126127993208889344.text:
It's too bad cz didn't try to reorg.

1125979237716983808.text: 7/ I lied. Binance is squeezed by time and risk. Every new block is another one that needs to be overtaken and costs 12.5 BTC minimum. Coordinating that quickly with the pools out there is likely not easy. The agreement process alone will take more than a day or 144 blocks. /fin

1125977500356677632.text: 6/ The losses are still at minimum 725 BTC which is still not a small chunk of change. /fin

1125977499643580417.text: 5/ Depending on the premium that a miner would charge for that risk, this would mean a much shorter time than 232 blocks to make that decision. And really, if you do this, you end up taking the money from the thieves and giving it to miners. Binance doesn't benefit that much.

1125977498934759425.text: 4/ There are significant risks also for the miners agreeing to do this as any miner that betrays will significantly raise the risk of wasting hash power that could be productively put to mining the longer chain.

1125977498318245888.text: 3/ 7250 BTC > 7000 BTC, so at minimum, you need more than 55% of all hashing power to agree to reorg the chain. In 58 more blocks, this rises to 60%, in 116 blocks, 65%. In 174 blocks, 70%, 232 blocks/75%. The cost goes up pretty quickly assuming everyone agrees.

1125977497663938561.text:
2/ If 75% of the network going with this scheme, you would need on average 116 blocks to overtake the current chain, or about 1450 BTC worth of mining rewards.
At 60%, this becomes 290 blocks or 3625 BTC. At 55%, 580 blocks/7250 BTC.

1125977497047314432.text:
1/ Back of the envelope math for doing a 58 block reorg (current confirmations for the tx that took money from binance):

1116093541602795523.text: 8/ This is what a non-exploitive, low time preference exchange looks like. They are concerned with keeping users on for the next 10 years, not to pinch users for pennies at every trade.

1116093540810088450.text: 7/ The differences with @LevelInvest are that the opportunity is available to anyone who wants it, that the vast majority of the profits go to the market maker instead of being shared with the exchange and there's real competition for market makers driving spreads down.

1116093538930966528.text: 6/ Users can put their coins toward automated market making to provide liquidity in exchange for a potential profit. Like any market making operation, there is risk, but there's also potential gain. Every user has an opportunity to earn money honestly by creating liquidity.

1116093538364731393.text: 5/ Market Making is traditionally only done by whales because each trade incurs cost and only whales get the rates low enough to make this activity worthwhile. But when you don't have per-transaction fees, you can do something else completely.

1116093537706291200.text: 4/ The company I'm advising, @LevelInvest is doing just that with a really innovative product that can only make sense in a fixed fee environment. Automated Market Making.

1116093537131671553.text: 3/ This is an exploitive model, and what's worse, whales get much better rates while the mass of smaller traders get even more screwed. But what if there was an exchange that put users first? What if that also leads to what matters most at exchanges? That is, liquidity?

1116093536418529285.text: 2/ They do this because they can and because they know you're used to the fees charged by traditional financial institutions, who always seem to charge you a transaction percentage.

1116093535864987649.text: 1/ Let's face it, most exchanges take as much money from you as they can, just up to the painful cost of finding another exchange with enough liquidity.

1113250548612988928.text: 8/ Learn your tools. For the love of God, please learn command line, git and a text editor like vim or emacs. You're most likely going to have to self-learn on these, but they're well worth your time. The time you can save pays back the investment manyfold.

1113250547610595328.text: 7/ Learn to present. Teach other coders what you've learned. Give management an overview. If you ever want to get ahead in your career, presenting is a skill you need. Putting a presentation together is not that different than coding, in any case.

1113250547031736326.text: 6/ Don't be afraid to learn. Too many devs are one trick ponies (*cough* Java *cough*). Learn new stuff or you'll grow stale. The ability to learn quickly is one of the most in-demand skills as a developer, so you'd best get started earlier than later.

1113250546310316032.text: 5/ Don't over-abstract. I blame this on OO. No, you don't need some super abstract class that can handle all cases. Just make the program do what you need it to. Abstract later when it makes sense, not before any other instance is written.

1113250545639264256.text: 4/ Write unit tests. Seriously, your QA teammates will thank you. You'll have less bugs. You'll understand your own code a lot better. You'll also make your code a lot more modular and testable. Yea, it takes more time, but you'll probably spend the time you save debugging later.

1113250545077190656.text: 3/ Code for readability. It's tempting to show off how clever you are by using some obscure language feature that does everything you want in one line. It's clever, but makes maintenance hard. The new grad that's reading your code will curse you. Don't be that guy.

1113250544519471105.text: 2/ Reliability is important. The new hot tech has those new features you've been dying to try! But it's also a giant mess, constantly updating, has bad documentation, is hard to set up and difficult to debug. Older tech has google-able solutions. You'll save time with older tech.

1113250543479263233.text:
Lessons to learn in your first 5 years as a programmer:

1/ Don't be afraid to do the same work multiple times. Your first try will often have a lot of bad design. You need repetitions before you get good. Don't let laziness get in the way of learning and improving.

1097598362415702022.text: 11/ This is the sort of opportunity that I always look for as an investor. Massively asymmetric bets. If it works, this company absolutely crushes other exchanges that can't compete on the low cost and the Coinbases of the world look like Blockbuster to Level's Netflix.

1097598361593675778.text: 10/ This is the next level of financial inclusion. You give users the ability to invest like the pros without the massive cost. You can have different strategies that can be iterated on. You can try stuff without it costing you a ton.

1097598360956084224.text: 9/ You don't need to charge on a per-trade basis to make a business work when you have software. That means all sorts of other things are possible like auto-rebalancing of portfolios and so on.

1097598360318607360.text: 8/ Software allows for great leverage and the fees from the traditional financial system are relics of the past that have been carried over by rent-seekers of various stripes. This is exactly the type of industry that's ripe for disruption by a much fairer model to customers.

1097598359710388224.text: 7/ At scale, you can definitely make a lot of money charging $5/user/month. Think about it. How much do you pay for Netflix? For GitHub? For World of Warcraft? These are software that are orders of magnitude more complicated than an exchange and they all still make lots of $$$.

1097598359039328258.text:
6/ After all, this is how it works in Bitcoin. 10,000 BTC transaction or 0.0001 BTC transaction both pay the same fees if they're the same size/weight.

In other words, cost can be significantly lowered with a different model for trading.

1097598358120792065.text: 5/ Exchanges have leveraged this to make a lot of $$$ and capture a ton of value. A $1M vs a $100 trade really isn't that different from a software point of view. They're the same database updates. Charging a % is not really necessary. A $1M trade doesn't cost 10000x a $100 trade

1097598357495791616.text: 4/ Second, most other industries have been disrupted by software. Software allows you to massively scale and provide a ton of value at very low marginal cost. The pricing, however, has been copied from the traditional financial services sector where it's usually a percentage.

1044041641437405184.text: 14/ Work on your virtues and the rest comes much more naturally. Perhaps you'll get rich, perhaps you won't. What's certain is that if you do create value the right way and become rich, that will be a lot more satisfying and fulfilling than doing so another way. /fin

1044041640401403904.text: 13/ Too many people want techniques without virtue. They're the chess player looking to learn more openings while having terrible tactics and endgame. They're the baseball pitcher looking to learn how to throw a curveball without being able to throw straight.

1044041639323480065.text: 12/ There's too much emphasis on how to create an idea, or how to raise money, or marketing techniques or hiring the right people or expanding your network. That is, the techniques. There's a place for techniques, but they're really only useful once you have virtue.

1044041638266511362.text: 11/ Hard work, discipline, tenacity, patience, courage, wisdom, self-awareness, reliability, kindness, focus and honesty are just some of the virtues that can create value.

1044041637285048320.text: 10/ The best way to wealth is to create value and what should be envied is what ultimately creates that value. The source of the wealth creation. We call these things virtues.

1044041635846377475.text: 9/ Stealing from others or getting lucky really doesn't add anything to anyone. You are at best neutral, and at worst making the world worse. This is ultimately unsatisfying.

1044041634965532672.text: 8/ Wealth is the natural consequence of doing something that's valuable to society *and* capturing at least some of that value.

1044041633942175744.text: 7/ Most people don't distinguish between getting lucky, stealing or earning when thinking about how to get rich. Their envy of the rich is simply that they are rich. This is the wrong way to think about wealth.

1044041632880963585.text: 6/ Or you could be rich because you created a business, provided a good or service, provided value to others in such a way as to get them to pay you. That is, you could have earned it.

1044041632016936960.text: 5/ Or you could be rich because you ponzi-scammed a bunch of people, embezzled from your company, kidnapped some wealthy person or committed burglary. That is, you could have stolen.

1044041630993526786.text: 4/ You could be rich because you inherited a lot of money, won the lottery, got a hot stock tip or found some sunken treasure by accident. That is, you could have gotten lucky.

1044041629907243008.text: 3/ What they miss is that being rich is not in itself a virtue. Being rich is the result of something else.

1044041628883845121.text: 2/ Many people look at rich people and think "why am I not that rich?" or "that person must be really lucky" or some other envious thought.

1044041628091133952.text: 1/ How to get rich the right way

Sunday Survey:

What is your occupation?

1025889677507801096.text: 9/ I predict that as bitcoin becomes a bigger part of society, that there will be more creativity, innovation, future orientation and civilization building than ever before. In other words, merit will be rewarded because hard money will exist. That's the path to meritocracy. /fin

1025889676173955072.text: 8/ That is a sad state of affairs and the reason why hard money is so important. Bitcoin is hard money. Bitcoin fixes a lot of stuff without intending to, like most fundamental changes.

1025889674445905920.text: 7/ Instead, we have entire classes of people that don't add anything but extract rent from everyone else. You have to give not only your money to them, but also your time, attention, energy and in many cases, reputation.

1025889673443528704.text: 6/ When you have hard money, you have to add value to earn it. You have to provide something people actually find useful. This in turn makes people very literally creative. As in creating stuff that makes civilization richer.
